Is it safe to merge my D and C drives?

The only reservation I have with merging these drives is if you have applications installed on the D: drive. Applications generally don't care to have their bits moved about. If you do have applications on there then take the time to uninstall them from D: and reinstall on C:.

If you need or want to keep the D: drive and still merge the partitions, that is possible using using the (rather obscure but built in) subst command to create a virtual D: drive using a folder on C:

Here is how to do it.

  • Copy everything from D: to C:\D_Drive

The only reservation I have with merging these drives is if you have applications installed on the D: drive. Applications generally don't care to have their bits moved about. If you do have applications on there then take the time to uninstall them from D: and reinstall on C:.

If you need or want to keep the D: drive and still merge the partitions, that is possible using using the (rather obscure but built in) subst command to create a virtual D: drive using a folder on C:

Here is how to do it.

  • Make a folder on C: called D_Drive.
  • Copy everything from D: to C:\D_Drive
  • Delete the D: partition
  • Stretch your C: partition
  • Then run: subst d: c:\D_Drive
  • Like magic, you now have a D drive again, and no wasted space


With all that said, now here is why you might want to keep a separate drive for your Data. By the volume label of the C: drive I'm going to infer that you don't have a copy of Windows to reinstall if things go awry. Most OEM "Recovery Images" blow away everything on the C: drive if you apply them. If you keep your data on a dedicated drive then you can survive these events without having to schlep everything off onto a USB drive first.

Best of Luck.

Many ancient Buddhist temples in India were converted into Hindu temples after the decline of Buddhism in the region. This was often due to the spread of Hinduism and the decline of Buddhism, as well as political and cultural changes that led to the appropriation of Buddhist sites by Hindu rulers.

Here are a few examples of ancient Buddhist temples that were converted into Hindu temples:

  • The Mahabodhi Temple in Bodh Gaya, Bihar, which was originally a Buddhist temple but was later converted into a Hindu temple dedicated to the god Vishnu.
  • The Sun Temple in Konark, Odisha, which was originally a Buddhist temple but was later converted into a Hindu temple dedicated to the sun god Surya.
  • The Elephanta Caves near Mumbai, which were originally Buddhist rock-cut caves but were later used by Hindu devotees.
  • The Ajanta and Ellora Caves in Maharashtra, which contain both Buddhist and Hindu rock-cut temples and are testimony to the religious syncretism that existed in ancient India.

These examples highlight the complex religious and cultural history of India and the interplay between different religious traditions over time.

How do earthquake resistant buildings work?

If a building's foundation sits on soft or filled-in soil, the whole building may fail in an earthquake regardless of the advanced engineering techniques employed.

However, if the soil beneath a structure is firm and solid, engineers can greatly improve how the building-foundation system will respond to seismic waves by tying the foundation to the building so the whole structure moves as a unit.

Another technique-- known as base isolation -- involves floating a building above its foundation on a system of bearings, springs or padded cylinders. Usually lead-rubber bearings, which contain a solid

If a building's foundation sits on soft or filled-in soil, the whole building may fail in an earthquake regardless of the advanced engineering techniques employed.

However, if the soil beneath a structure is firm and solid, engineers can greatly improve how the building-foundation system will respond to seismic waves by tying the foundation to the building so the whole structure moves as a unit.

Another technique-- known as base isolation -- involves floating a building above its foundation on a system of bearings, springs or padded cylinders. Usually lead-rubber bearings, which contain a solid lead core wrapped in alternating layers of rubber and steel are chosen for this purpose. The lead core makes the bearing stiff and strong in the vertical direction, while the rubber and steel bands make the bearing flexible in the horizontal direction. Bearings attach to the building and foundation via steel plates and then, when an earthquake hits, allow the foundation to move without moving the structure above it. As a result, the building's horizontal acceleration is reduced and suffers far less deformation and damage.

Even with a base-isolation system in place, a building still receives a certain amount of vibrational energy during an earthquake. The building itself can dissipate, or damp, this energy to some extent, although its capacity to do this is directly related to the ductility of the material used in the construction. Brick and concrete buildings have low ductility and therefore absorb very little energy. This makes them especially vulnerable in even minor earthquakes. Buildings constructed of steel-reinforced concrete, on the other hand, perform much better because the embedded steel increases the ductility of the material. And buildings made of structural steel offer the highest ductility, allowing buildings to bend considerably without breaking.

Installing damping systems is also an effective technique to protect the building from earthquakes. Active mass damping, for example, relies on a heavy mass mounted to the top of a building and connected to viscous dampers that act like shock absorbers. When the building begins to oscillate, the mass moves in the opposite direction, which reduces the amplitude of mechanical vibrations. It's also possible to use smaller damping devices in a building's brace system.

Many ancient Buddhist temples in India were converted into Hindu temples following the decline of Buddhism in the country. The conversion of Buddhist temples into Hindu temples was part of a larger trend of religious assimilation and integration that took place in India over the centuries, as different religious and cultural traditions were absorbed into the Hindu religion.

Some of the most notable examples of ancient Buddhist temples that were converted into Hindu temples include:

  • The Ajanta Caves: The Ajanta Caves were built in the 2nd century BCE as Buddhist monasteries and were later converted into Hindu temples.
  • The Ellora Caves: The Ellora Caves were built between the 6th and 10th centuries CE and include both Buddhist, Hindu, and Jain temples. Some of the Buddhist temples were later converted into Hindu temples.
  • The Mahabodhi Temple: The Mahabodhi Temple was originally built as a Buddhist temple and is believed to have been the site of the Buddha's enlightenment. It was later converted into a Hindu temple and is now a major pilgrimage site for Buddhists and Hindus alike.
  • The Sanchi Stupa: The Sanchi Stupa was built in the 3rd century BCE as a Buddhist shrine, but it was later converted into a Hindu temple and is now considered a sacred Hindu site.

It's worth noting that these conversions took place over a long period of time, and the exact process of conversion varied from temple to temple. In some cases, Buddhist symbols were simply replaced with Hindu symbols, while in other cases the entire temple was rebuilt as a Hindu temple. Nevertheless, the conversion of Buddhist temples into Hindu temples reflects the complex and fluid religious landscape of ancient India, and the enduring legacy of Buddhism in the country.

And each temple is consecrated with elaborate rituals specific to the deity enshrined in the temple. So there is absolutely no possibility of a Buddhist temple, which has none of these requirements being turned into a Hindu temple.

Did Hindu Kings also destroy Temples and lo0t Idols during medieval times? This is one of the frequently asked questions, especially during debates on Izl@mic invaders destroying Hindu Temples. Leftist intellectuals cleverly manipulate such facts to confuse & push young Hindus on the backfoot through such propaganda, and surprisingly, there is no proper counter-argument from right wing to explain the actual logic & reasonings.

The simple fact is that there were indeed some instances of Hindu Kings taking out Idols from Temples of the defeated/acquired kingdom, and relocating it to their own capital city. It is to be noted that it was not a forceful or vi0lent act against the devotees, but more of a ritual, which was actually supported & encouraged by the devotees themselves.

Why? Because in any Kingdom, there would be a capital city, acting as a Head Quarters (HQ), and that Kingdom's sacred God would be worshiped in a Temple located at such HQ, which would be like a matter of honor for the Idol. Now, consider a situation where another Kingdom defeats this Kingdom, which automatically makes this Kingdom a subsidiary (secondary). The devotees would feel that their idol is now not in the HQ, but in a defeated Kingdom, and hence would request the winning King to relocate their idol to the Victorious Kingdom, which he would promptly oblige.

That's how idols used to be relocated regularly across temples, to ensure that they get their highest honour at any given point of time, by worshiping them in a region which was considered victorious and ultimate at that point of time. Which is the biggest Hindu temple and a Buddhist temple?

Angkor Wat is a temple complex in Cambodia and the largest religious monument in the world. It was originally built as a Hindu temple dedicated to the god Vishnu, but later became a Buddhist temple. The temple is known for its impressive sandstone bas-reliefs, which depict scenes from Hindu mythology, as well as its beautiful towers and galleries. Angkor Wat is located in the city of Siem Reap, which is a popular tourist destination in Cambodia

Is Angkor wat a Buddhist temple or Hindu?

Angkor Wat was a Hindu temple, built by Suryavarman II (which was completed by Jayavarman VII) of Khmer empire in 12th century AD. It was constructed in the city which was then called Yashodhapura, which served as capital of Khmer empire.

The temple started to become a Buddhist temple from 17th century onwards, gradually.

There are many sculptures and bas reliefs that explains stories of Hindu puranas. Notably, many inscriptions in the temple are also in Sanskrit.

Angkor Wat was a Hindu temple, built by Suryavarman II (which was completed by Jayavarman VII) of Khmer empire in 12th century AD. It was constructed in the city which was then called Yashodhapura, which served as capital of Khmer empire.

The temple started to become a Buddhist temple from 17th century onwards, gradually.

There are many sculptures and bas reliefs that explains stories of Hindu puranas. Notably, many inscriptions in the temple are also in Sanskrit.

Churning of milk:

A scene from Mahabharata:

A royal procession from Ramayana:

An on-going fight scene from Ramayana:

One striking similarity is the script used in inscriptions.

A inscription from Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu, India.

A similar style of writing can be seen at Angkor Wat.

Both are in Sanskrit language, while the writing system is different (in case of Mahabalipuram, it is Grantha and in case of Cambodia, it is Khmer).

So, to summarise, Angkor Wat was a Hindu temple, that became a Buddhist temple.

What is Buddhist temple called?

It really depends on the school, tradition or country as to what its called. Names like gonpa or ling (Tibetan Buddhism), Vihara (Theravadin), Wat (Thailand, Laos and Cambodia) are some of the names used for Buddhist temples in the native tongues. In English they are simply called Buddhist temples and this is not disrespectful.

How do Hindu temples differ from Buddhist or Jain temples?

Hindu means Indian.

So asking how are Hindu temples different from Bauddha or Jaina temples is meaningless. After all, Bauddha and Jaina are Hindu darsana, with their own sampradaya.

You could instead reword it to: How are Bauddha and Jaina temples different to the temples of the other sampradaya like Sikhi, Shaiva, Shakta, Vaishnava and so on.

You could say that there is no difference since all temples are a focal point for the community which they serve. And the purpose of all temples is to educate you about yourself and by inference, your dharma!

However there is an essential difference.

Vaishnava temples for example educate the masses through a visual representation of the nature of reality, with the sanctum containing the material representation or vigraha of the focal point of practices, which is nothing but a higher human ideal that defines a path to the ultimate objective, which is moksha. It also educates you on the other ideals and qualities (represented by other deities) essential to realizing your objective through mnemonic narratives (folklore) associated with the main deity.

Bauddha and Jaina temples instead focus on educating scholars (monks) of their tradition on the teachings of the Buddha and the Jaina Tirthankaras and are hence usually part of a larger complex that houses the students and teachers.

While the education in Vaishnava temples involves passive learning, those in Bauddha and Jaina temples involve active learning. Active learning for scholars in the Vaishnava tradition happens only in a Gurukula.

Did Hindu kings destroy Jain and Buddhist temples?

No. During the time when Hinduism declined, esp. in south and western India, Buddhism received royal patronage and they did take over and convert many Hindu temples including the Tirupati balaji temple plus many temples that are now sastha/Karthikeya temples in Kerala and Tamil Nadu. Many of the Karthikeya temples on mountain tops or hillocks in TN had been converted to Buddhist temples. After Hinduism got revival through Bhakti movement, they aggressively took back the Hindu temples converted into Buddhist ones. This included Tirupati temple, which itself is said to have been a Karthikeya tem

No. During the time when Hinduism declined, esp. in south and western India, Buddhism received royal patronage and they did take over and convert many Hindu temples including the Tirupati balaji temple plus many temples that are now sastha/Karthikeya temples in Kerala and Tamil Nadu. Many of the Karthikeya temples on mountain tops or hillocks in TN had been converted to Buddhist temples. After Hinduism got revival through Bhakti movement, they aggressively took back the Hindu temples converted into Buddhist ones. This included Tirupati temple, which itself is said to have been a Karthikeya temple.

The fact that the Dalai Lama visits and worships at Tirupati is itself proof of it having been taken over by Buddhists.
